titleStmt.title: [University of Chicago Library GMS-0019, a manuscript catalogue description in electronic form]
titleStmt.funder: Institute of Museum and Library Services

publicationStmt.publisher: University of Chicago Library, Special Collections Research Center

overview.p: Gospel Harmony in Latin. Initials of gospels Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John (M, m, L, J), and chapter numbers noted in red above the first word of each recorded passage. Titles of gospel sections in adjacent margins, and in the table of contents. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Lat. 1.

initials.p: Major initials (10-15 mm) in blue ink with penwork flourishes in red. Minor initials in red or blue. The first letter of the opening word of most verses is highlighted in yellow.

watermarks.p: Watermark for quires 2 through 7 similar to Briquet, Balance dans un cercle 2447 (Gurck 1448, Munich 1450-1459, Hungary 1453-1470, Vienne 1454-1459). For quires 8, 9, and fol. 116, the watermark is similar to Briquet, Tour 15872 (Wied, 1477, Halberstadt, 1446, Gnessen, 1448).

physDesc.extent: 120 leaves, of which 3 are flyleaves. Flyleaves conjoint with pastedowns.

foliation.p: 2 (unfoliated flyleaves) + 117 + 1 (unfoliated flyleaf). Modern foliation in Arabic numerals in pencil 1-117. Earlier foliation of leaf openings in red.

collation.p: Quires 1 through 9 of 12 leaves, the 10th quire is of 9 leaves. It is presumed the prologue, table of contents, and table description were bound initially in front of the Harmony's main text.

At the beginning and end of the table of contents, the titles of gospel sections on lost leaves range from the conception of John the Baptist to his imprisonment by Herod Antipas, and from Jesus's cleansing of the temple to his ascension.

physDesc.catchwords: Catchwords at the end of quires 1 through 9.

layout.p: 1 column, 24 to 26 lines (variants of 22 to 27 lines). Frame ruling with lead point.

handDesc.p: Written in cursive script mainly in dark brown ink (moderate fading).

condition.p: Some marginal titles and ink foliation marred owing to trimming. Several leaves detached at the end of the manuscript. Random water, dirt, and grease stains.

binding.p: Bound with parchment pieces of 2 missals upon which square musical notation (no staff lines), text, and penwork flourishes are visible. Phrase on back inside cover [s]eruorum tuorum..., possibly Psalm 73:22.

origin.p: The manuscript is dated to the 15th century, and may have been written in Germany.

provenance.p: Provenance unknown from the 15th to the mid-19th century. Belonged to German Lutheran theologian Ernst Wilhelm Hengstenberg (1802-1869), his surname inscribed in pencil (front flyleaf). Belonged also to the Baptist Union Theological Seminary of Chicago, Illinois which purchased Hengstenberg's Library from his heirs, December 1869.

University of Chicago Libraries bookplate and stamp (front pastedown, flyleaf). Inscriptions and notation: adi 17 marzo 1550 io do zuav..., maria di nargarado, ego johanes + Caminus[?] (front flyleaf); Carissimo amant[issim]o m[esser] barba Sariti contento di mandarmi (fol. 111v); este liber est mei (back flyleaf, recto); adi 17 marzo 1550 io do.... (back flyleaf, verso); hec sine numine domini[?] eveniunt, este liber est mei domini....(back pastedown).

acquisition.p: Acquired by the University of Chicago when the Baptist Union Theological Seminary became the university's Divinity School, ca. 1892.

projectDesc.p: The Edgar J. Goodspeed Manuscript Collection contains 68 Greek, Armenian, Latin, Syriac, Ethiopic, and Arabic manuscripts, which range in date from the fifth to the nineteenth century. With support from the Institute of Museum and Library Services National Leadership Grants for Libraries, Building Digital Resources program, the University of Chicago Library has created the online Goodspeed Manuscript Collection, a unique digital resource with manuscripts digitized in their entirety and presented with high-quality zoomable images through an interface that supports browsing within individual manuscripts and across the collection.

Descriptions of the manuscripts have been encoded using the standard set forth in TEI Consortium, eds., TEI P5 Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange: Manuscript Description, at http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/MS.html as of 2012-09-22.

The TEI DTD used was obtained from the Digital Scriptorium of Columbia University at, https://www1.columbia.edu/sec/cu/libraries/bts/digital_scriptorium/technical/ds-xml/description_dtd/index.html on 2012-09-22. To accommodate specific project needs, the DTD was edited and extended with local tags in order to describe the content of miniatures, and the structure of canon tables, headpieces, and initials. The process of editing included equating the element Decoration with the seven recognized elements of the TEI Manuscript Description, not only to emphasize intellectual substance, but also to augment visibility by providing links from the record through encoding to the digitized imagery of the Web display.

overview.p: Gospel Harmony in Latin. Initials of gospels Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John (M, m, L, J), and chapter numbers noted in red above the first word of each recorded passage. Titles of gospel sections in adjacent margins, and in the table of contents. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Lat. 1.

msItem.incipit: Fuit in diebus Herodis regis Iudaeae sacerdos quidam nomine Zaccharias de vice Abia (Luke 1:5)
msItem.explicit: ...praedicaverunt ubique Domino cooperante et sermonem confirmante sequentibus signis (Mark 16:20).
msItem.rubric: Ihesus dulcis memoria da nobis te in tua gloria amen.

msItem.incipit: Reliquit ihesus Iudaeam terram et abiit in Galilaeam
msItem.explicit: ...eicere vendentes et ementes in templo cum introisset in coepit.
msItem.rubric: Explicit tabula super evvangelium domini nostri et salvatoris ihesu christi filii dei et virginis marie domini nostre.

msItem.incipit: Sequitur rubricha ad intelligendum ipsam tabulam....
Cum evvangelistarum legissem volumina reperissemque in eis signa multa ac verba domini ihesu
msItem.explicit: ...qui non studiosse sed ignoranter composui credems ac firmiter tenens que mater ecclesia per omnia tenet.

bibl.title: The Story of the Goodspeed Collection
